title: Glenn.Gould.Collection.Vol.I.AVC.AC3.720p.Parts1&2
description:
This torrent contains NÃ‚Âºs 01 and 02 from the collection "Volume 1" of the same DVD indicated under torrent #11140626. This part (01) was introduced with the title "Beethoven Piano Sonata Op 110" and then goes on to add: 

"III Adagio ma non troppo Fuga Allegro ma non troppo"

Now I have to admit I know nothing about the numbering system for classical music, just as I know nothing about the "Dewey Decimal System" (DDS) for cataloging books in libraries. However, I don't really want to know about it unless it's completely trivial. So I'm just going to take it as being trivially simple from whence we can deduce the meanings of all those funny numbers:

It follows therefore, that a "Sonata" is a type of work and an "Opus" number is an index pertaining to categories of works which makes this the 110Ã¡Âµâ€”ÃŠÂ° Sonata by Beethoven. It also follows that complete works contain segments (like the songs on an album) and those would be called "Movements"

So, by assumption of simplicity:

    Ã¢â‚¬Â¢ One X == One Album of type "X" by composer "C"
    Ã¢â‚¬Â¢ Opus# == NÃ¡Âµâ€”ÃŠÂ° X by C
    Ã¢â‚¬Â¢ Movement# == NÃ¡Âµâ€”ÃŠÂ° Song from "Opus N" of type "X" by "C"

So we can write down, if we want, the exact specification any part of any piece in the following format:

Composer.Category(Op-type).OpNum.MovementNum and Ã¢â‚¬Â¦

Now the last bit: "III Adagio ma non troppo Fuga Allegro ma non troppo" must be the movement number and a short description pertaining to how it aught to be played (codec in today's lingo).

So I went to look up the Latin and "Adagio ma non troppo Fuga Allegro ma non troppo" translates to "Slow but not too slow fast but not too fast" (ie. Don't go too slow on the slow bits and don't go too fast on the fast bits) in other words "Low Tempo Modulation" which I will call LTM.

Thus we have: "Beethoven.Sonata.110.3.LTM"
